33.fullDescription:
A possible integer overflow exists in the function `Command(address,bytes)`.
The addition or multiplication may result in a value higher than the maximum representable integer.
33.name: ArithmeticVulnerability

30.fullDescription: A possible transaction order independence vulnerability exists in function withdraw(). The value or direction of the call statement is determined from a tainted storage location
30.name: FrontRunningVulnerability

20.fullDescription:
Multiple sends exist in one transaction, try to isolate each external call into its own transaction. As external calls can fail accidentally or deliberately.
Consecutive calls: 
Call at address: 922
20.name: OtherVulnerability

20.fullDescription: A possible transaction order independence vulnerability exists in function withdraw(). The value or direction of the call statement is determined from a tainted storage location
20.name: FrontRunningVulnerability

21.fullDescription:
In the function `GetFreebie()` a non-zero amount of Ether is sent to msg.sender.
It seems that this function can be called without restrictions.
21.name: AccessControlVulnerability

40.fullDescription: This contract executes a message call to an address provided as a function argument. Generally, it is not recommended to call user-supplied addresses using Solidity's call() construct. Note that attackers might leverage reentrancy attacks to exploit race conditions or manipulate this contract's state.
40.name: ReentrancyVulnerability

40.fullDescription: The return value of an external call is not checked. Note that execution continue even if the called contract throws.
40.name: UncheckedLowCallsVulnerability

15.fullDescription:
Freebie.GetFreebie (/data/demo_analysis/source_code/0xe82f0742a71a02b9e9ffc142fdcb6eb1ed06fb87.sol#15-25) sends eth to arbitrary user
	Dangerous calls:
	- msg.sender.transfer(this.balance) (/data/demo_analysis/source_code/0xe82f0742a71a02b9e9ffc142fdcb6eb1ed06fb87.sol#21-22)
15.name: AccessControlVulnerability

fullDescription.text:
A possible integer overflow exists in the function `Command(address,bytes)`.
The addition or multiplication may result in a value higher than the maximum representable integer.
A possible transaction order independence vulnerability exists in function withdraw(). The value or direction of the call statement is determined from a tainted storage location

Multiple sends exist in one transaction, try to isolate each external call into its own transaction. As external calls can fail accidentally or deliberately.
Consecutive calls: 
Call at address: 922

In the function `GetFreebie()` a non-zero amount of Ether is sent to msg.sender.
It seems that this function can be called without restrictions.

This contract executes a message call to an address provided as a function argument. Generally, it is not recommended to call user-supplied addresses using Solidity's call() construct. Note that attackers might leverage reentrancy attacks to exploit race conditions or manipulate this contract's state.
The return value of an external call is not checked. Note that execution continue even if the called contract throws.

Freebie.GetFreebie (/data/demo_analysis/source_code/0xe82f0742a71a02b9e9ffc142fdcb6eb1ed06fb87.sol#15-25) sends eth to arbitrary user
	Dangerous calls:
	- msg.sender.transfer(this.balance) (/data/demo_analysis/source_code/0xe82f0742a71a02b9e9ffc142fdcb6eb1ed06fb87.sol#21-22)
